facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 143 of 1957 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 143 of 1957. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated 8th May 1957 of Allahabad High Court in Criminal Reference No. 149 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: . Appeal from the judgment and order dated the 8th May, 1957, of the Allahabad High Court, in Criminal Reference No. 149 of 1956,

facts.text: Reference arose from judgment dated 14th January 1956 of First Additional Sessions Judge, Agra, in Sessions Trial No. 141 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated the 14th January, 1956, of the First Additional Sessions Judge, Agra, in Sessions Trial No. 141 of 1954

facts.text: Complaint filed by Rajendra Kumar Jain against four appellants and three others under sections 409, 465, 467, 471 and 477A IPC.

anchor.surface_text: A companyplaint was filed by Rajendra Kumar Jain against the four appellants and three others under ss. 409, 465, 467, 471 and 477A of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Summonses issued to accused under section 406 IPC after statement under s.200 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: Suffice it to say that after the statement of the companyplainant under s. 200 of the Code of Criminal Procedure hereinafter referred to as the Code  summonses were issued

facts.text: Prosecution witnesses examined and cross-examined, statements of accused recorded.

anchor.surface_text: to the accused persons requiring them to answer a charge under s. 406 of the Penal Code. Prosecution witnesses were then examined and cross-examined

facts.text: Arguments on framing of charges concluded on September 23, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate then heard argu- ments on the question of framing of charges which were companycluded on September 23, 1954.

facts.text: Case put up on September 30, 1954 for orders.

anchor.surface_text: It was then ordered that the case should be put up on September 30, 1954, for orders.

facts.text: On September 30, 1954, Magistrate framed charges against four appellants under ss. 409 and 465 read with s. 471 and 477A IPC and ordered commitment to Sessions Court.

anchor.surface_text: On that date the Magistrate framed charges against the four appellants under ss. 409 and 465 read with s. 471 and 477A of the Penal Code. On the same date the Magistrate ordered companymitment

facts.text: Remaining three accused discharged on September 30, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: of the four appellants to the Court of Session on these charges. The remaining three accused were discharged.

facts.text: Revision petition filed by Rajendra Kumar Jain against discharge of Bhajan Lal.

anchor.surface_text: There was then a revision petition by Rajendra Kumar Jain against the discharge of one of the three accused, namely, Bhajan Lal.

facts.text: First Additional Sessions Judge, Agra ordered suo motu on April 9, 1955 that Bhajan Lal be committed to Sessions Court.

anchor.surface_text: When the matter came up before the First Additional Sessions Judge Agra, he ordered suo motu on April 9, 1955, after a perusal of the companymitment order

facts.text: Sessions Judge dismissed revision petition as infructuous.

anchor.surface_text: that Bhajan Lal be companymitted to the Court of Session to stand his trial. In view of this order he dismissed the revision petition as infructuous.

facts.text: Bhajan Lal filed revision to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon Bhajan Lal went in revision to the High Court.

facts.text: Roy J. of High Court set aside commitment order of Bhajan Lal on October 6, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: That petition was heard by Roy, J., and he set aside the order of companymitment of Bhajan Lal ... This order was passed on October 6, 1955.

facts.text: Reason by Roy J.: Magistrate not empowered to frame charge and commit until accused evidence taken.

anchor.surface_text: one of the reasons given by him for doing so was that a Magistrate was number empowered to frame a charge and make an order of companymitment until he had taken all such evidence as the accused might produce before him.

facts.text: Four appellants filed revision on January 7, 1956 before Sessions Judge to quash commitment order for non-compliance with ss.208-213 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon on January 7, 1956, the four appellants filed a revision petition before the Sessions Judge praying that the order of companymitment passed against them be quashed ... ss. 208 to 213 of the Code

facts.text: First Additional Sessions Judge made reference to High Court on January 14, 1956 that commitment bad due to irregular procedure.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated the 14th January, 1956, of the First Additional Sessions Judge, Agra ... This reference came up for bearing before another learned Judge

facts.text: Chowdhry J. rejected reference, held no non-compliance with s.208, ss.211-212 curable under s.537 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: This reference came up for bearing before another learned Judge of the High Court, namely, Chowdhry, J., and he took the view that the Magistrate had number failed to companyply with the provisions of s. 208 ... curable under s. 537 of the Code.

facts.text: Certificate granted by High Court for appeal to Supreme Court due to conflict with Roy J. view.

anchor.surface_text: There was then an application for a certificate to appeal to this Court which was allowed, particularly, as the view taken by Chowdhry, J., was in companyflict with the view taken by Roy, J.,

facts.text: Magistrate did not inform accused of intention to commit under s.347 CrPC and deprived right to produce defence evidence under s.208.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate, however, failed to inform the accused that -he had made up his mind to proceed under s. 347  1  and to companymit them for trial. What he did on September 30, 1954,

facts.text: Supreme Court held commitment bad in law due to non-compliance with s.208 CrPC, not curable under s.537.

anchor.surface_text: The companymitment is, therefore, bad in law and must be quashed on this ground alone.

anchor.surface_text: The main contention of the appellants before us is that as the case began before the Magistrate as a warrant case under s. 406 of the Penal Code, it was incumbent upon the Magistrate, when he decided, in view of the provisions of s. 347  1  of the Code, that the case should be committed to the Court of Session, to follow the procedure provided in Ch. XVIII of the Code and inasmuch as he had failed to comply with ss. 208 to 213 of the Code the commitment was bad in law and should be quashed.

anchor.surface_text: The main contention of the appellants before us is that as the case began before the Magistrate as a warrant case under s. 406 of the Penal Code, it was incumbent upon the Magistrate, when he decided, in view of the provisions of s. 347 1 of the Code, that the case should be committed to the Court of Session, to follow the procedure provided in Ch. XVIII of the Code

arguments.court_reasoning: Confirmed; Magistrate failed to inform and allow s.208 defence.

arguments.claim: Proceedings before Magistrate began as trial of warrant case under s.406, not inquiry under Ch.XVIII; summons only under s.406 gave no notice of commitment; Magistrate must inform accused if intending Ch.XVIII under s.207/s.347.

anchor.surface_text: We must say with respect that this view of the nature of the proceedings before the Magistrate is not correct. It is true that it is open to a Magistrate to hold an inquiry from the beginning under Chapter XVIII in a case not exclusively triable by the Court of Session.

arguments.claim: Words 'under the provisions hereinbefore contained' in s.347 mean provisions in Ch.XVIII; High Courts unanimous.

anchor.surface_text: The first question that has to be decided is the meaning of the words under the provisions hereinbefore contained . These words have been the subject of decision by a number of High Courts and the High Courts are unanimous that they mean that if the Magistrate decides at some stage of the trial to commit the accused,

arguments.claim: When Magistrate decides under s.347 to commit, must inform accused and comply with remaining Ch.XVIII provisions (ss.208-213) from that stage; essential to safeguard s.208 right to defence evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate, however, failed to inform the accused that he had made up his mind to proceed under s. 347 1  and to commit them for trial. What he did on September 30, 1954, was to frame charges forthwith and record an order committing the accused to the Court of Session under s. 213 of the-Code.

arguments.claim: Non-compliance with s.208 (denial of defence evidence opportunity) presumes prejudice to accused; not curable under s.537 as per Pulukuri Kottaya and Subramania Iyer (trial conducted differently from prescribed manner).

anchor.surface_text: The next question which falls for consideration is the effect of this non-compliance with s. 208 of the Code and whether it is curable under s. 537 of the Code. ... The commitment is, therefore, bad in law and must be quashed on this ground alone.

arguments.claim: Breach of ss.211,212,213 need not be considered as breach of s.208 alone suffices to invalidate commitment.

anchor.surface_text: In the petition of appeal the appellants have referred also to breach of provisions of ss. 211, 212 and 213 of the Code. As we have come to the conclusion that the breach of s. 208 in this case is sufficient to invalidate the commitment it is not necessary to consider the effect of the further breach of ss. 211, 212 and 213.

holdings.text: The proceedings before the Magistrate began as in the trial of a warrant case and if the Magistrate at a subsequent stage of the proceedings was of the view that the case should be committed to the Court of Session, he would have to act under s. 347 of the Code.

anchor.surface_text: We must say with respect that this view of the nature of the proceedings before the Magistrate is not correct. It is true that it is open to a Magistrate to hold an inquiry from the beginning under Chapter XVIII in a case not exclusively triable by the Court of Session.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Summons issued only under s.406 (non-exclusive sessions offence); no indication from outset of inquiry under Ch.XVIII; accused reasonably expect trial unless informed otherwise.

holdings.text: The words 'under the provisions hereinbefore contained' in s.347 mean the provisions contained in Ch. XVIII.

anchor.surface_text: The first question that has to be decided is the meaning of the words under the provisions hereinbefore contained . These words have been the subject of decision by a number of High Courts and the High Courts are unanimous that they mean that if the Magistrate decides at some stage of the trial to commit the accused,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation confirmed by unanimous High Court precedents; requires compliance with Ch.XVIII procedure upon decision to commit.

holdings.text: When a Magistrate decides under s.347 to commit a case not exclusively triable by Sessions which began as warrant trial, he must intimate that decision to the accused to safeguard right under s.208 and comply with remaining Ch.XVIII provisions from that stage.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate, however, failed to inform the accused that he had made up his mind to proceed under s. 347  1  and to commit them for trial. What he did on September 30, 1954, was to frame charges forthwith and record an order committing the accused to the Court of Session under s. 213 of the-Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.347 requires commitment 'under provisions hereinbefore contained' (Ch.XVIII); s.208 mandates defence evidence opportunity before charge/commitment; must inform to trigger procedure.

holdings.text: The Magistrate failed to inform the accused of his intention to commit under s.347 and deprived them of their right to produce defence evidence under s.208.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate, however, failed to inform the accused that -he had made up his mind to proceed under s. 347  1  and to commit them for trial. What he did on September 30, 1954,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Magistrate framed charges and committed forthwith on Sep 30, 1954 without intimating s.347 decision or calling for defence evidence.

holdings.text: Breach of s.208 presumes prejudice to accused as it denies right to produce defence evidence before charge/commitment; such breach causes failure of justice and is not curable under s.537.

anchor.surface_text: The question, therefore which eventually emerges is whether this breach of s. 208 is of such a character that the Court will presume that there has been prejudice to the accused by the mere fact of the breach.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Pulukuri Kottaya and Subramania Iyer: denial of statutory right to defence evidence before commitment affects Magistrate's charge decision; prejudice presumed, no s.537 cure.

holdings.text: The commitment is bad in law and must be quashed on the ground of non-compliance with s.208.

anchor.surface_text: The commitment is, therefore, bad in law and must be quashed on this ground alone.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative: began as warrant trial; failed to inform/invoking s.208 right; presumes prejudice, incurable.

holdings.text: It is not necessary to consider the effect of breaches of ss.211, 212 and 213 as breach of s.208 suffices to invalidate the commitment.

anchor.surface_text: In the petition of appeal the appellants have referred also to breach of provisions of ss. 211, 212 and 213 of the Code. As we have come to the conclusion that the breach of s. 208 in this case is sufficient to invalidate the commitment it is not necessary to consider the effect of the further breach of ss. 211, 212 and 213.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.208 breach alone decisive; other issues moot.

anchor.surface_text: One of the earliest of these case decided by the Privy Council is Subramania Iyer King-Emperor  1 , while one of the latest is Pulukuri Kotayya v. King-Emperor 2 . The law was summed up by their Lordships of the Judicial Committee in Pulukuri Kotayyas case

precedents.cited_proposition: Distinction between trial conducted substantially in prescribed manner with irregularity (curable under s.537) and trial conducted differently (bad)
precedents.cited_holding: When a trial is conducted in a manner different from that prescribed by the Code as in N.A. Subramania Iyers case, the trial is bad... if the trial is conducted substantially in the manner prescribed by the Code, but some irregularity occurs... the irregularity can be cured under s. 537

anchor.surface_text: When a trial is conducted in a maner different from that prescribed by the Code  as in N.A. Subramania Iyers case  1 , the trial is bad, and no question of curing an irregularity arises
